Hi;

I was hoping someone had come up with a way to test them outside the server.
I actually wrote a framework like that 2 years ago (at another company). It
called the bean directly, not through the home/remote i/f. It allowed me to
test during the build process.

I think running the tests after we deploy is probably the best bet. (We run
regular tests as part of our build process.)

thanks - dave


-----Original Message-----
From: Sameera Balay [mailto:sb@...]
Sent: Tuesday, June 26, 2001 8:46 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] How to test EJBs?


We do the same for EJB testing. Just treat them as regular classes. We
treat a JUnit as any client to the EJB and test all the public methods.
We did not have any problem so far testing our EJB's this way. As John
mentioned in setUp create the EJB and in the tear down delete it.

Sameera

-----Original Message-----
From: John Stetic [mailto:johns@...]
Sent: Tuesday, June 26, 2001 9:38 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] How to test EJBs?


Your post is kind of vague.  You are asking a big question.  We are just
treating EJB like any other classes.  We create the EJB in the set up
method
and then delete it in the tear down.  As long as you have the EJB
deployed
to a running app server, your off to the races.

This is really a good topic for discussion.  Anyone else what to share
there
experiences with EJB testing?  I have heard allot about Cactus, How does
it
fit in to the whole thing?  (Now my post is the vague one <grin>)

John
